user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_SetDeferredRetcode:
```c
void UT_SetDeferredRetcode(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 Count, UT_IntReturn_t Retcode)
{
    /* The count should always be a positive integer, if not there is a bug in the test */
    if (Count <= 0)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("BUG: Invalid Count (%ld) passed to UT_SetDeferredRetcode()", (long)Count);
    }
    else
    {
        UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(FuncKey, &Retcode, sizeof(Retcode), UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, Count, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_SetDeferredRetcode:
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
...
void UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize,
                                        UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre, int32 Counter, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    UT_EntryType_t       ReqEntryType;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);

    /*
     * For deferred retval configs, this always adds a new entry.  But
     * for constant retval configs, it should replace the existing entry if
     * there is one.
     */
    if (Counter > 0)
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_DEFERRED;
        StubPtr      = NULL;
    }
    else
    {
        ReqEntryType = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETVAL_CONFIG_CONSTANT;
        StubPtr      = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, ReqEntryType);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
    }

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Abort("Cannot configure return value - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
    }
    else
    {
        StubPtr->FuncKey = FuncKey;

        StubPtr->EntryType         = ReqEntryType;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Genre    = ValueGenre;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Counter  = Counter;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.ActualSz = ValueSize;
        StubPtr->Data.Rvc.TypeName = TypeName;

        if (ValueGenre == UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE)
        {
            /* For "unknown" types the pointer is stored directly - this allows for ANY return type of ANY size,
             * but requires that the caller maintain the buffer in scope until the test completes */
            StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf.IndirectPtr = ValuePtr;
        }
        else
        {
            /* For any of the recognized typical return types, a copy is made and stored in the state buffer */
            UT_StoreRetval(&StubPtr->Data.Rvc.Buf, ValuePtr, ValueSize, ValueGenre);
        }
    }
}
...
static UT_StubTableEntry_t *UT_GetStubEntry(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, UT_EntryType_t TestMode)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr   = NULL;
    uint32               Idx       = FuncKey % (UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS - 1); /* hash the key to determine the start point */
    uint32               SearchLen = 0;
    uint32               SearchLimit;
    UT_EntryKey_t        SearchKey;

    /* If searching for an unused entry, look through the entire table.
     * Otherwise bound the search */
    if (TestMode == UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED)
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS;
        SearchKey   = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        SearchLimit = UT_MaxStubSearchLen;
        SearchKey   = FuncKey;
    }

    while (1)
    {
        if (SearchLen >= SearchLimit)
        {
            StubPtr = NULL;
            break;
        }
        ++SearchLen;
        StubPtr = &UT_StubTable[Idx];
        if (StubPtr->EntryType == TestMode && StubPtr->FuncKey == SearchKey)
        {
            break;
        }
        ++Idx;
        if (Idx >= UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS)
        {
            Idx = 0;
        }
    }

    /*
     * Keep track of the longest search length since the last reset.
     * This serves as the upper bound for future searches.
     */
    if (SearchLen > UT_MaxStubSearchLen)
    {
        UT_MaxStubSearchLen = SearchLen;
    }

    return StubPtr;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The listed fragments are those that require inspection for potential unreachable-code issues: the assertion call site in UT_SetDeferredRetcode (UtAssert_Failed) and the related control-flow in UT_ConfigureGenericStubReturnValue and UT_GetStubEntry where certain branches or earlier assignments may never have an effect depending on the inputs or on whether assertion/abort helpers terminate execution. Other parts of the provided code were not flagged because they do not contain obviously constant/always-true or always-false conditions or unreachable statements by inspection: - The ValueGenre conditional (opaque vs. non-opaque) is data-dependent and reachable for different callers, so neither branch is intrinsically unreachable. - UT_StoreRetval and the non-opaque handling are reachable when ValueGenre is not UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE. - The loop and search-limit logic in UT_GetStubEntry are runtime-dependent on SearchLimit/SearchLen and can terminate either by finding an entry or by hitting the search limit; there is no evident always-unreachable region inside it. - Assignments that may be redundant (e.g. initial StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(...) overwritten later) were only flagged where they affect control-flow reasoning; otherwise redundancy alone does not by itself prove unreachable code. Reviewers should focus on the flagged fragments to determine if assertions/aborts are non-returning (making subsequent code unreachable) or if certain branches can never be taken given how the APIs are used across the project.
